Message.Msg: You are not correct. You measured to at least six significant digits past the decimal point so your answer (average) could have at least six significant digits too. If you required a real world accuracy of seven significant digits after the decimal then I think you would express your "real" mean as 10.0000000. Or maybe 10.000000. If you are building electronic parts or space ship parts or nuclear fission gizzmos maybe seven significant digits would be important. Expressing your "true value" as 10 would imply that 10 +/- 0.5 is OK! (Thus a range of 9.5 to 10.5.) This might be OK for estimating jelly beans in a box, but might be wholly inadequate for precision mechanics. (I worked around actuaries and statisticians for many years.) I suppose there are valid scientific measurements where billionths can be accurately measured. In most real world cases billionths are not reasonably measurable. Or meaningful. In insurance it is common to round to the nearest whole dollar. In reinsurance we sometimes needed to calculate reinsurance rates to the nearest penny and sometimes to the nearest 1/10th penny to get useful reinsurance premiums. Note that in your example, if we rounded your calculated average to 9.3 we would have a more accurate estimate approaching your given "true value" (e.g. mean) of 10.

Then somebody finds a bunch of stars that are way bigger! So we re-estimate, and so on. There is no way we can ever get the "true" average. Here you go, we produce 10,000 cases of jelly beans per day. Each case has a gross of boxes of jelly beans. On average, how many jelly beans are in each box. We want to assure our customers that there are at least 10 jelly beans in a box and not more than 13 jelly beans in a box at least 90% of the time. Remember that we are producing 10,000 new cases of jelly beans every day! We won't ever know what the "true" mean is! We must just estimate it within a range of confidence. Here's another one: In a certain auto rating territory, within a state, we have 3375 insureds covered for collision insurance. Last year there were 1182 accidents invoking collision coverage for a total paid loss of $2,805,645.94. What will the average loss per policy be NEXT year? You can only ESTIMATE the answer within a range of confidence! (Trust me, people using fancy statistics lose on this one every year!)

Topic.Title: a challenge on significant digits issues by the board scientist

Message.Msg: I think I originally started this "thread" by asking how satellites could determine the temperature on the ground to the millionth of a degree, e.g. 9.9999999 since most thermometers are incapable of that refined a measurement. I noticed a lot of satellite temperatures are to the seventh digit after the decimal point. Global warming is usually expressed to the 10th degree C: 0.4 degrees C in the last 100 years (or maybe 0.7 degrees C depending on whose story you're reading.) In my experience 1/10th degree is the limit for most ground based thermometers. At the time you gave an adequate answer that there were statistical methods & proofs for calculating more refined "significant digits" then may have existed in the original data. I still question weather that makes any practical difference in the real world, if your equipment is not capable of measuring it. Saying that warming has increased by 0.3 degrees C (0.7 - 0.4 = 0.3) but doesn't mean much to me since the implied range is 0.25 to 0.35 with an average of 0.3 degrees C.) Then we compare that to the measured temperature (which is maybe 23.4 degrees C[guessing]) and find that our "variation" is 668.6 to 936.0 times less significant than our measured temperature. I am sorry, I wonder if this is really meaningful.
